 >It appears that a number sequence is
>presented on an input, along with additional inputs corresponding to 
>various program instructions.

That's right. The network is evaluated several times in order to 
construct the program, which is essentially an array of instructions. 
On each evaluation, the network can see a single entry in the number 
sequence, and also a single instruction in the program. The intention 
here is that, if necessary, the network can navigate back and forth 
within the program to change instructions.

>Output appears to be threshold applied 
>to select the program instruction w/ highest output.

Yes, along with an ability to navigate through the program list and/or 
number sequence. This is probably needlessly complicated for the task.

>The outputs 
>corresponding to the sequence is tested for length and correctness as 
>applies to the status of the stack.

Once the network has been evaluated MAX_STEPS times, the generated 
program is evaluated at each index in the number sequence, and the 
differences between its output and the supplied sequence are totalled. 
If the program fails to evaluate for any reason, an error of 100 is 
assumed.

Fitness is computed based upon
>cumulative error over input sequence. It appears that cost is tracked 
>but does not appear to factor into fitness?

It is divided down and added to the cumulative error in line 2882. 
Cost was probably a fairly ill-thought out attempt to help NEAT find 
more sophisticated networks, by making the more disruptive 
instructions expensive.

I'll freely admit that this experiment wasn't thought through terribly 
well, as it fell more into the "I wonder if this might work" realm 
than a serious investigation. The main reasons for uploading the file, 
as I recall, were the shape recognition experiments, so I'm not sure 
really how much use the program experiment could be.

--Darren
